extracted_ttps.description: Emotet uses social engineering to trick users into opening a malicious Excel attachment and bypassing Microsoft's Mark-of-the-Web detection
Emotet returns and deploys loaders through phishing campaigns using email thread hijack technique
Emotet spreaders use Excel maldoc with sheet protection to hide malicious macros
Emotet operators use social engineering to lure users into executing malicious documents
Emotet uses a phishing email with a malicious document attachment to infect the target
Attacker used PowerShell to download and execute a malicious script (tps1.ps1) which downloads an additional dll (bb.dll) associated with Bumblebee malware
Emotet malware is distributed via spearphishing attachments, specifically XLS maldocs
Password protection of Office can be broken via a well-known brute force technique
The attacker uses a malicious Excel formula to download and execute a file when the workbook is opened
The attacker adds multiple keys to the Windows registry to execute the DLLs at every restart
Emotet may use PowerShell to execute commands, although not explicitly stated in this text, it is a common technique used by Emotet
Emotet uses social engineering to coerce the user into copying the Excel file into the Microsoft Office Templates folder
The user is tricked into opening the malicious XLS maldocs, which may lead to the execution of Emotet malware
Emotet uses Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH) and Elliptic-curve digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) for encrypted communication
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: Bumblebee malware communicates with its C2 servers to potentially exfiltrate data
The attacker uses the URLDownloadToFileA function to download files from specified URLs
PowerShell is used for execution, as indicated by the detection of PowerShell in the NLP analysis findings
Emotet delivers a new module that executes XMRig, a Monero miner, to hijack system resources
Emotet executes macros in the Excel attachment when opened in the Templates folder
Emotet may use legitimate web services to hide its command and control activities
Emotet's developers use logical operations to build IP addresses and ports of C2 servers
indicators: IP addresses and ports of C2 servers

extracted_ttps.description: PowerShell is used by Emotet for execution
IcedID malware communicates with its C2 server, potentially for application window discovery
Emotet malware is spread through an Excel document, which requires user execution
Emotet uses PowerShell to execute malicious commands
The attacker uses the regsvr32.exe binary to execute the downloaded DLLs
Emotet relies on user interaction to execute malicious macros
Emotet uses code obfuscation to hide its malicious intentions
Emotet is executed by users through phishing campaigns
The attacker uses a Korean IP address (182.162.143.56) for communication
Emotet relies on users to execute malicious documents
Emotet may use WMI to gather information about the system
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
Emotet may use system information discovery for reconnaissance

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: Emotet communicates with C2 servers to exfiltrate data

Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Suspicious Process Spawned from Excel with Command Shell
rules.description: Detects Excel spawning command-line shells which may indicate malicious macro or script execution from a phishing attachment, potentially bypassing Mark-of-the-Web controls.

detection.condition: selection and spawntocmd and (commandline_keywords or templates_folder)

falsepositives: Legitimate automation scripts launched from Excel via VBA (rare in most environments)
Administrative or developer tools launched manually from Excel (uncommon)
Enterprise management tools that integrate with Excel (very rare)

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Office Process Spawning Shell With Encoded Command
rules.description: Detects Emotet maldocs using email thread hijack technique to spawn command shells from Office applications with suspicious command-line parameters

detection.condition: selection_parent and selection_child and (selection_cli or selection_path)

falsepositives: Legitimate Office macros using shell commands (rare)
Administrator scripts executed through document templates

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: PowerShell execution downloading malicious script or DLL with suspicious parent process
rules.description: Detects PowerShell processes that execute or download the known malicious script tps1.ps1 or DLL bb.dll, or access raw disk devices, when spawned from common shells such as cmd.exe or explorer.exe.

detection.condition: (selection_ps or selection_dll or selection_disk) and (parent_cmd or parent_explorer)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative PowerShell scripts that reference .ps1 files
Software that legitimately accesses raw disks (e.g., disk imaging or backup tools)
System maintenance tasks that invoke PowerShell from cmd.exe or explorer.exe

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Brute Force Detection
rules.description: Detects brute force attempts to crack Office passwords
falsepositives: Legitimate password reset tools
Scripts that contain 'password' or 'crack' in the command line

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Malicious Excel Execution via Command Line with Known URLs
rules.description: Detects Excel spawning command shells with URLs associated with malicious user execution
falsepositives: Legitimate Excel macros or automation scripts using command-line tools with these specific URLs (unlikely given malicious nature)

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Persistence via New Service with Specific DLL Paths
rules.description: Detects creation of Windows services using sc.exe or PowerShell referencing known malicious DLL paths for persistence (T1543.003).
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative service creation using these exact paths (unlikely given random folder names)

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detect PowerShell Execution with Encoded Commands and Disk Wiping Activity
rules.description: Detects PowerShell processes using encoded command flags and execution of known disk wiping tools or direct raw disk access, which are indicative of Emotet's Command and Scripting Interpreter technique and destructive behavior.

detection.condition: selection_powershell or selection_powershell2 or selection_disk_wipe or selection_disk_access

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative PowerShell scripts that use -EncodedCommand or -enc for obfuscation
System administrators using SDelete or DBAN for secure data disposal
Built‑in Windows utilities that access raw disks (e.g., diskpart.exe, format.com) when launched from PowerShell or cmd

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detects Emotet Encrypted Communication via ECDH/ECDSA Keys
rules.description: Detects processes using Emotet's known ECDH or ECDSA keys in command lines spawned from common shells
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using similar cryptographic keys (unlikely)
Security tools testing encryption parameters

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Bumblebee Malware C2 Exfiltration via Shell Processes
rules.description: Detects Bumblebee malware data exfiltration through command shells connecting to known C2 infrastructure
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts connecting to rare IP addresses
Penetration testing tools

rules.title: Ingress Tool Transfer via URLDownloadToFileA and Disk Wiping Tool Execution
rules.description: Detects use of URLDownloadToFileA (typically via rundll32.exe) to download files from known malicious URLs and execution of known disk wiping utilities or direct hard‑disk access, indicating potential data exfiltration preparation or destructive activity.

detection.condition: (download_process and (parent_cmd or parent_ps)) or download_url1 or download_url2 or download_url3 or download_url4 or wipe_sdelete or wipe_dban or wipe_direct

falsepositives: Legitimate system maintenance scripts that use rundll32.exe with urlmon.dll for approved updates.
Administrative use of sdelete.exe for secure file deletion.
DBAN or other disk wiping utilities used by IT staff in controlled environments.
Scripts or tools that download files from internal or trusted web servers matching similar URL patterns.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious XMRig Monero Miner Execution

falsepositives: Legitimate cryptocurrency mining operations
Security researchers analyzing mining software

rules.title: Application Window Discovery via Legitimate Web Services

rules.title: Detection of Malicious C2 IP and Disk Wiping Tool Execution
rules.description: Detects network connections to the known malicious Korean IP address (182.162.143.56) and execution of common disk‑wiping utilities (DBAN, SDelete, generic wipe tools) when launched from a command shell or PowerShell, indicating potential command‑and‑control activity and data destruction.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of DBAN or SDelete by administrators for secure data disposal.
Network traffic to the IP address for benign purposes (e.g., corporate VPN endpoint) if the address is ever repurposed.

rules.title: Persistence via Registry Run Keys and Execution of Disk Wiping Tools
rules.description: Detects creation or modification of Run registry keys and execution of known disk wiping utilities or direct disk access commands, indicating potential persistence setup or destructive activity.

detection.condition: reg_hklm or reg_hkcu or dban or sdelete or diskwipe or format or disk_wipe_behavior or disk_wipe_behavior_ps

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that add entries to HKLM or HKCU Run keys.
Authorized use of format.com or diskpart.exe for disk management.
System administrators using SDelete or other secure deletion tools for data sanitization.
Software installers that create startup entries via reg.exe.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detection of Disk Wiping Tools Execution via Sysmon
rules.description: Detects execution of known or custom disk wiping tools (e.g., DBAN, SDelete) either directly or via a shell, using low‑level device paths or suspicious parent processes. This covers the User Execution: Malicious File technique (T1204.002).
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative use of SDelete or other secure deletion utilities
Windows built‑in tools such as cipher.exe /w, format.com, or diskpart.exe used for disk management
Scripts or imaging software that reference \Device\Harddisk\ for legitimate purposes

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

attacks.description: Opens a potentially malicious Excel file using PowerShell, demonstrating how social engineering could lead to the execution of malicious Excel macros.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens an Excel file in the temporary directory, potentially executing any macros it contains.

attacks.description: Downloads and executes a file from a URL, simulating a phishing attack where a user is tricked into downloading and running malicious software.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from the specified URL and executes it, demonstrating a potential phishing vector.

attacks.description: Another example of opening a potentially malicious Excel file, this time using Reflection to load the Excel assembly, demonstrating variations in tactics.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens an Excel file without making changes or enabling editing, simulating the viewing of a malicious document.

attacks.command: echo 'Please run this command to update your system: bash /tmp/malicious_script.sh' | mail -s 'System Update Required' user@example.com
attacks.description: Simulate a phishing email that tricks the user into running a malicious bash script.
attacks.expected_behavior: The user receives an email prompting them to run a command that could potentially execute malicious code.

attacks.description: Download a file from a URL and execute it as a bash script, simulating a phishing attack that relies on user interaction to download and run malicious code.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file and attempts to execute it, potentially leading to malicious code execution if the file is harmful.

attacks.description: Create a malicious script, make it executable, and then run it, demonstrating how a phishing attack could lead to the execution of malicious code on a Linux system.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system creates and executes a potentially malicious script, posing a significant risk if the script contains harmful commands.

attacks.description: Basic: Create a benign loader file in the temp directory using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named testloader.txt will be created in the temp directory with the specified content.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Use certutil to download a benign file from a local web server to the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named testfile.txt will be downloaded from the specified local URL and saved to the temp directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[Convert]::ToUtf8String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes('This is a test string')) | Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\testencoded.txt -Encoding utf8"
attacks.description: Advanced: Utilize PowerShell to encode a test string to UTF-8 and write it to a file, ensuring proper encoding handling.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named testencoded.txt will be created in the temp directory containing the specified test string encoded in UTF-8.

attacks.description: Downloads a script from a URL and executes it using bash.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be downloaded and executed, potentially leading to malicious activity.

attacks.description: Downloads a payload, makes it executable, and then runs it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload will be downloaded, made executable, and then executed, which could lead to malicious activity.

attacks.description: Creates a local script with a malicious command and executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be created and executed, running the malicious command.

attacks.description: Downloads a PowerShell script from a URL and executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script tps1.ps1 is downloaded to the temp directory and then executed.

attacks.description: Downloads a DLL file, potentially associated with malware, using TLS 1.2 for secure connection.
attacks.expected_behavior: The DLL file bb.dll is downloaded to the temp directory.

attacks.description: Starts a new PowerShell process to execute a previously downloaded script, demonstrating indirect execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new PowerShell window opens and executes the tps1.ps1 script.

attacks.description: Basic command to download and execute a PowerShell script from a URL.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a PowerShell script and executes it. The script could potentially download additional files.

attacks.description: Intermediate command that downloads a dll file and attempts to import it as a module, simulating the download of additional malware components.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a dll file and attempts to import it, which could lead to the execution of malicious code if the dll were actual malware.

attacks.description: Advanced command that creates a directory, downloads a script into it, and then executes the script, demonstrating a more complex scenario of malware deployment.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a directory, downloads a script, and executes it. This could lead to the deployment of actual malware if the script and dll were malicious, hence the high safety risk.

attacks.command: for /l %x in (1,1,100) do net user test %x /add
attacks.description: Basic brute force attempt to add a user with a simple incremental password
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to add a user with passwords from 1 to 100, demonstrating a basic brute force approach

attacks.description: Intermediate brute force attempt using PowerShell to add a user with incremental passwords
attacks.expected_behavior: Similar to the basic command but utilizes PowerShell for the brute force attempt

attacks.command: certutil -f -v -urlcache -split http://example.com/wordlist.txt && for /f %x in (wordlist.txt) do net user test %x /add
attacks.description: Advanced brute force attempt using a wordlist from a hypothetical local file to add a user
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a wordlist (assuming it's locally accessible or replacing the URL with a local path) and attempts to use each word as a password to add a user, simulating a more sophisticated brute force attack

attacks.command: for pass in {0000..9999}; do echo $pass >> passwords.txt; done; hydra -l user -P passwords.txt ssh://localhost
attacks.description: Basic brute force attack using a password list generated on the fly and hydra to attempt SSH login
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to login via SSH with a series of passwords, demonstrating brute force technique

attacks.command: echo 'user:pass' > credentials.txt; while IFS=: read -r user pass; do sshpass -p $pass ssh $user@localhost 'echo Success'; done < credentials.txt
attacks.description: Intermediate brute force attack using sshpass to automate SSH login attempts with a list of credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to login via SSH using a list of credentials, demonstrating brute force with automation

attacks.command: seq 0000 9999 > pins.txt; for pin in $(cat pins.txt); do echo -e "$pin" | sudo -S id; done
attacks.description: Advanced brute force attack simulating a PIN entry for sudo access, iterating through a range of numbers
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to guess the sudo PIN, demonstrating a more targeted brute force attack

attacks.description: Downloads a file from a local web server using certutil and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The file will be downloaded to the temp directory and executed

attacks.description: Opens a malicious Excel file using PowerShell, which can execute a malicious formula
attacks.expected_behavior: The Excel file will be opened, and the malicious formula will be executed

attacks.description: Opens a malicious Excel file using the start command, which can execute a malicious formula
attacks.expected_behavior: The Excel file will be opened, and the malicious formula will be executed

attacks.description: Downloads a benign bash script and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be downloaded and executed, printing a benign message

attacks.description: Downloads a benign bash script using wget and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be downloaded and executed, printing a benign message

attacks.description: Downloads and executes a benign bash script using a bash subshell
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be downloaded and executed, printing a benign message

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Run" /v TestService /t REG_SZ /d "C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe /c echo Test Service" /f
attacks.description: Basic: Adds a new registry key to run a command at startup using reg.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key is added under HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Run to execute a command at startup.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Uses PowerShell to add a new registry key for executing a command at startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: Similar to the basic command, but utilizes PowerShell for more complex operations.

attacks.command: sc create TestService binPath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe /c echo Test Service" && sc start TestService
attacks.description: Advanced: Creates and starts a new service using sc.exe to execute a command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new service named TestService and starts it, executing the specified command. This method directly interacts with the service control manager.

attacks.command: sudo systemctl start myservice && sudo systemctl enable myservice
attacks.description: Start and enable a new service using systemd
attacks.expected_behavior: The service will start and be enabled to run at startup

attacks.command: sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/myservice.service && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl start myservice
attacks.description: Create a new service file, reload systemd, and start the service
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service file will be created, and the service will start

attacks.command:
sudo echo '[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/echo "Hello World" > /tmp/hello.txt
' > /etc/systemd/system/myservice.service && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl start myservice
attacks.description: Create a new service file with a benign command, reload systemd, and start the service
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service file will be created with a benign command, and the service will start, writing to /tmp/hello.txt

attacks.description: Advanced execution with install parameter
attacks.expected_behavior: regsvr32.exe installs and then executes the test.dll from %TEMP%, demonstrating a more complex attack scenario

attacks.description: Compile a shared library and execute it using ldd
attacks.expected_behavior: The ldd command will load the shared library and execute the malicious function.

attacks.command: echo 'int main() { system("/bin/bash"); return 0; }' > /tmp/m.c && gcc -shared -o /tmp/libm.so -fPIC /tmp/m.c && ldd /tmp/libm.so
attacks.description: Create a C program that executes a shell, compile it to a shared library, and execute it using ldd
attacks.expected_behavior: The ldd command will load the shared library and execute the shell.

attacks.description: Create a shared library from an object file and execute it using ldd
attacks.expected_behavior: The ldd command will load the shared library and execute the malicious function.

attacks.description: Encode a benign string using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create an encoded file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Decode the encoded string using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will print the decoded string to the console

attacks.description: Create an obfuscated file using net.exe and encode it using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create an obfuscated file in the temp directory and encode it

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation using base64 encoding
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file with base64 encoded content

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation using AES encryption
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an encrypted file with a password

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation using hex encoding and recovery
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hex encoded file and recovers the original binary

attacks.description: Basic test of connectivity to a remote server on port 80 using telnet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a connection to the specified IP address on port 80 if the server is listening and the connection is not blocked by a firewall.

attacks.description: Intermediate example using PowerShell to create a temporary file and then initiate a telnet connection to a remote server on port 443.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temporary files directory with the content 'Hello, World!' and then attempts to establish a telnet connection to the specified IP address on port 443.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo open 182.162.143.56 21 > %TEMP%\ftp.txt & echo quit >> %TEMP%\ftp.txt & ftp -s:%TEMP%\ftp.txt & del /q %TEMP%\ftp.txt"
attacks.description: Advanced example using cmd.exe to create a temporary FTP script file, initiate an FTP connection to a remote server on port 21, and then clean up the temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary file ftp.txt with commands to open an FTP connection to the specified IP address on port 21 and then quit. It then executes this script using the ftp command and finally deletes the temporary script file.

attacks.description: Basic netcat command to establish a connection to the Korean IP address on port 80
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish a connection to the Korean IP address on port 80

attacks.description: Intermediate netcat command to establish a connection to the Korean IP address on port 443 with verbosity and a timeout
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish a connection to the Korean IP address on port 443 with verbosity and a timeout

attacks.description: Advanced netcat command to establish a UDP connection to the Korean IP address on port 53 with verbosity and a timeout
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish a UDP connection to the Korean IP address on port 53 with verbosity and a timeout

attacks.description: Retrieve operating system details using WMI.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays operating system information, such as version, build number, and service pack details.

attacks.description: List all running processes on the system using WMI.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes, including their process IDs, names, and memory usage.

attacks.description: Retrieve user account information using WMI.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user account details, such as usernames, account types, and status.

attacks.command: wmic /node:localhost /namespace:\\\\oot\\cimv2 path win32_operatingsystem get name
attacks.description: This command attempts to use WMIC to connect to the local machine and retrieve the name of the operating system. Note: This would typically require a Windows system or a WMI client installed on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should return the name of the operating system if successful, demonstrating interaction with WMI.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to get the WMI object for the operating system and retrieve its name. It assumes PowerShell is installed and configured on the Linux system.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should output the name of the operating system, showing successful interaction with WMI via PowerShell.

attacks.description: This command uses winexe, a tool that allows running commands on remote Windows machines, to query WMI for the operating system name. It requires appropriate credentials and setup.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should return the name of the operating system on the remote Windows machine if credentials are correct and winexe is properly configured.

attacks.description: Basic invocation of PowerShell to list processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running processes

attacks.description: Intermediate command creating a directory and file in the user's temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory and a file within the temp directory

attacks.description: Advanced command encoding a PowerShell command and saving it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes the 'Get-Process' command and saves the encoded string to a file

attacks.description: Basic command to get the current date
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will print the current date and time

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World!'

attacks.description: Advanced command to download a webpage and save it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download the webpage from http://example.com and save it to a file named test.html in the temp directory

attacks.description: Gather system information, including OS version, hardware, and hotfixes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information in the command prompt.

attacks.description: Gather user information, including privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user information and privileges in the command prompt.

attacks.description: Gather network configuration information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays network configuration information in the command prompt.

attacks.description: Gather basic system information using uname
attacks.expected_behavior: Output basic system information, including kernel version and architecture

attacks.description: Gather detailed system information using /etc/os-release
attacks.expected_behavior: Output detailed system information, including distribution name and version

attacks.description: Gather Linux distribution information using lsb_release
attacks.expected_behavior: Output information about the Linux distribution, including distribution name and version

attacks.command: echo 'This is a benign payload' > %TEMP%\payload.txt && certutil -f -encode %TEMP%\payload.txt %TEMP%\payload.dat && powershell -Command "& {Start-Process -FilePath 'cmd' -ArgumentList '/c', 'type', '%TEMP%\payload.dat'}"
attacks.description: Create a text file, compress it using certutil, and execute the compressed file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The compressed file will be executed, and the contents of the text file will be displayed on the screen

attacks.description: Create a text file, compress it using Compress-Archive, and then expand the archive using Expand-Archive
attacks.expected_behavior: The compressed file will be expanded, and the contents of the text file will be available in the temp directory

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {$bytes = [System.IO.File]::ReadAllBytes('%TEMP%\payload.txt'); $ms = New-Object System.IO.MemoryStream; $ms.Write($bytes, 0, $bytes.Length); $ms.Position = 0; $compressed = New-Object System.IO.Compression.DeflateStream($ms, [System.IO.Compression.CompressionMode]::Compress); $out = New-Object System.IO.FileStream('%TEMP%\payload.dat', [System.IO.FileMode]::Create); $compressed.CopyTo($out); $out.Close(); $ms.Close(); $compressed.Close()}" && powershell -Command "& {Start-Process -FilePath 'cmd' -ArgumentList '/c', 'type', '%TEMP%\payload.dat'}"
attacks.description: Create a text file, compress it using DeflateStream, and execute the compressed file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The compressed file will be executed, and the contents of the text file will be displayed on the screen

attacks.description: Basic command to create a tarball and gzip it, simulating software packing.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tarball named test.tar.gz containing test.txt in the current directory.

attacks.command: echo 'test_string' > test.txt; tar -czf test.tar.gz test.txt; base64 test.tar.gz > encoded_test.txt
attacks.description: Intermediate command that not only packs the file but also encodes it in base64, adding an extra layer of evasion.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tarball named test.tar.gz containing test.txt and then encodes this tarball in base64, saving it as encoded_test.txt.

attacks.command: echo 'test_string' > test.txt; tar -czf test.tar.gz test.txt; base64 test.tar.gz > encoded_test.txt; gzip -d < encoded_test.txt | base64 -d | tar -xzf -
attacks.description: Advanced command that demonstrates the full cycle of packing, encoding, and then unpacking and decoding the file, simulating the delivery and execution of packed malware.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tarball, encodes it, and then decodes and unpacks it, demonstrating the full cycle of software packing and unpacking.

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe /c echo 'Test Service' > %TEMP%\test.txt"
attacks.description: Create a new service named TestService that executes a command to write to a temp file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service is created, and upon start, it writes 'Test Service' to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task named TestTask that executes a command to write to a temp file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task is created, and daily, it writes 'Test Task' to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.command: net.exe stop TestService && net.exe start TestService
attacks.description: Stop and then start the TestService service, demonstrating modification of a system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService service is stopped and then started again, modifying its state.

attacks.description: Start a new system service using systemd
attacks.expected_behavior: The command starts a new system service named 'myservice' if it exists, demonstrating the creation or modification of a system process.

attacks.description: Open crontab for editing to schedule a command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: The command opens the crontab file for editing, allowing the user to schedule a command execution, thus modifying system process scheduling.

attacks.description: Create a new init script using sysvinit
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a new init script named 'myscript' and configures it to start at the default run levels, demonstrating the creation or modification of a system process.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign file from a URL using certutil, simulating a potential exploit of a public-facing application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file named benign_file.exe to the temporary directory without executing it, demonstrating the initial step of exploiting a public-facing application.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to download a benign file, simulating an exploit with more advanced capabilities.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a benign file to the temporary directory, demonstrating an exploit using PowerShell for more complex operations.

attacks.description: An advanced PowerShell command that downloads a file using .NET classes, simulating a sophisticated exploit.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a benign file to the temporary directory, showing a more complex method of exploiting a public-facing application.

attacks.description: Simulate a basic public-facing application exploit using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should send a GET request to the specified URL with the exploit parameter set to true, simulating a basic exploit attempt.

attacks.description: Simulate an intermediate public-facing application exploit using bash and curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should create a log file in /tmp, write an exploit attempt message to it, and then append the result of a curl request to the same log file, simulating a more complex exploit attempt.

attacks.command: bash -c 'mkdir /tmp/exploit-dir -p; echo "Advanced exploit attempt" > /tmp/exploit-dir/exploit.log; curl -X POST -d "exploit=true" http://example.com/vulnerable-page >> /tmp/exploit-dir/exploit.log'
attacks.description: Simulate an advanced public-facing application exploit using bash, mkdir, and curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should create a directory in /tmp, write an advanced exploit attempt message to a log file within that directory, and then append the result of a curl POST request to the same log file, simulating a sophisticated exploit attempt.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Test > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Basic: Add a registry key to execute a command when a user logs in
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory when a user logs in

attacks.description: Intermediate: Add a registry key to execute a PowerShell command when a user logs in
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory when a user logs in

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c certutil -urlcache -f http://example.com/test.txt %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Advanced: Add a registry key to execute a command that downloads a file when a user logs in
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be downloaded from example.com and saved in the temp directory when a user logs in

attacks.description: Adds a cron job to touch a file every minute, simulating periodic execution via a run key equivalent.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named testfile will be created or updated every minute in /tmp, indicating successful execution of the cron job.

attacks.command: sudo systemctl enable --user test.service; sudo systemctl start test.service
attacks.description: Enables and starts a systemd service named test.service, simulating persistence through a Linux equivalent of a run key.
attacks.expected_behavior: The test.service will be enabled to start at user login and will be started immediately, demonstrating persistence.

attacks.command: (crontab -l ; echo "@reboot /usr/bin/echo 'Test command executed at reboot'") | crontab -
attacks.description: Adds a cron job to execute a command at system reboot, simulating a run key that triggers at startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: Upon the next system reboot, the command will execute, printing 'Test command executed at reboot' to the console or system logs, indicating successful execution of the reboot cron job.

attacks.description: Open a text file in notepad to simulate user execution of a potentially malicious file
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad will open with a new file named test.txt in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create a PowerShell script and execute it to simulate user execution of a malicious file
attacks.expected_behavior: A PowerShell script will be created and executed, printing 'Hello World' to the console

attacks.description: Create a batch file and execute it to simulate user execution of a malicious file
attacks.expected_behavior: A batch file will be created and executed, printing 'Hello World' to the console

attacks.command: bash -c "echo 'This is a test string' > ~/testfile.txt && chmod +x ~/testfile.txt && ~/testfile.txt"
attacks.description: Basic example of creating and executing a file with a test string.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named testfile.txt in the user's home directory, makes it executable, and then executes it, printing the test string to the terminal.

attacks.description: Intermediate example using a shell script to execute a command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a shell script named intermediate_test.sh, makes it executable, and then executes it, printing 'Intermediate test' to the terminal.

attacks.description: Advanced example involving the creation and execution of a file with an advanced test string, demonstrating indirect execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named advanced_test.txt, makes it executable, and then uses bash to execute it, printing 'Advanced test string' to the terminal.
